liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You just heard Opposition Leader Peter Dutton saying Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was "missing in action" when the Jewish community "needs him most". Mr Albanese was quick to respond, saying it was an attempt for Mr Dutton to "weaponise anti-semitism". He called the speech "beyond contempt". "I spoke in this chamber on Monday about the events in Caulfield and about the events in the eastern suburbs of Sydney," Mr Albanese said. "There was no qualification, no qualification whatsoever, in my condemnation. "At a time when there is social division, leaders have a choice, they have a to either bring people together or divide them." Mr Albanese added he was against the "idea of selective human rights". "Now, Jewish Australians are fearful at the moment," he said. "The sort of activity that is occurring is scaring them and I stand with them. "No-one should threaten people because of their religion or their race in this country. "But it is also the case that Arab Australians, and Islamic Australians, and women wearing hijabs in the streets of Sydney and Melbourne are being threatened and I stand against that as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No qualification, whatsoever, in my condemnation': Mr Albanese

children.content: You just heard Opposition Leader Peter Dutton saying Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was
"missing in action" when the Jewish community "needs him most".
Mr Albanese was quick to respond, saying it was an attempt for Mr Dutton to "weaponise anti-semitism".
He called the speech "beyond contempt".
"I spoke in this chamber on Monday about the
events in Caulfield
and about the events in the eastern suburbs of Sydney," Mr Albanese said.
"There was no qualification, no qualification whatsoever, in my condemnation.
"At a time when there is social division, leaders have a choice, they have a to either bring people together or divide them."
Mr Albanese added he was against the "idea of selective human rights".
"Now, Jewish Australians are fearful at the moment," he said.
"The sort of activity that is occurring is scaring them and I stand with them.
"No-one should threaten people because of their religion or their race in this country.
"But it is also the case that Arab Australians, and Islamic Australians, and women wearing hijabs in the streets of Sydney and Melbourne are being threatened and I stand against that as well."

props.alt: Anthony Albanese stands in front of Parlliament house

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says Mr Dutton's comments were "beyond contempt".
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Meanwhile in Australia, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is "missing in action" when the Jewish community "needs him most". Mr Dutton criticised Mr Albanese for heading overseas amid growing tensions in Australia as a result of the Israel-Gaza war. He also criticised Labor for what he says were divided views on how to address the conflict. "This Prime Minister is flying off overseas again when he should be staying in this country to deal with the issue," Mr Dutton said during Parliament Question Time. "What could he do, he says, what could he possibly do about it? "This Prime Minister needs to stand up and to be united with the Jewish community and he's not. "The words have been qualified, the message divided." His statement comes as he writes to Mr Albanese to pressure him to hold a national cabinet meeting to discuss the domestic implications of the Israel-Gaza conflict.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Missing in action': Peter Dutton criticises PM's response to rising anti-semitism

featuredLink.title: Dutton calls on PM to hold national cabinet on Australian implications of Israel-Gaza conflict

children.content: Meanwhile in Australia, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is "missing in action" when the Jewish community "needs him most".
Mr Dutton criticised Mr Albanese for heading overseas amid growing tensions in Australia as a result of the Israel-Gaza war.
He also criticised Labor for what he says were divided views on how to address the conflict.
"This Prime Minister is flying off overseas again when he should be staying in this country to deal with the issue," Mr Dutton said during Parliament Question Time.

props.alt: Peter Dutton sits in front of a group in Parliament house

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton say Prime Minister Anthony Albanese needs to stand up and "be united" with the Jewish community.
(ABC News)
"What could he do, he says, what could he possibly do about it?
"This Prime Minister needs to stand up and to be united with the Jewish community and he's not.
"The words have been qualified, the message divided."
His statement comes as he writes to Mr Albanese to pressure him to hold a national cabinet meeting to discuss the domestic implications of the Israel-Gaza conflict.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A White House National Security Council spokesperson says "we don’t want to see a firefight in a hospital" in response to Israel's military operation inside Al-Shifa. "We do not support striking a hospital from the air and we don't want to see a firefight in a hospital where innocent people, helpless people, sick people trying to get medical care they deserve are caught in the crossfire," the spokesperson who did not wish to be named tells Reuters. "Hospitals and patients must be protected." Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Hospitals and patients must be protected': White House National Security Council spokesperson

children.content: A White House National Security Council spokesperson says "we don’t want to see a firefight in a hospital" in response to Israel's military operation inside Al-Shifa.

"We do not support striking a hospital from the air and we don't want to see a firefight in a hospital where innocent people, helpless people, sick people trying to get medical care they deserve are caught in the crossfire," the spokesperson who did not wish to be named tells Reuters.
"Hospitals and patients must be protected."
Reporting with Reuters

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street sends Australian stocks higher, while the third-quarter wage price index is due out today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX jumps, wages grew 1.3 per cent in Q3, Singtel responsible for Optus outage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The September quarter wage growth was the strongest on record, annual pay rise was the biggest since March 2009. Base wages rose 1.3 per cent over the three months to September and 4 per cent over the past year. Wages were pushed higher by a 5.75 per cent boost for workers on awards and a 15 per cent pay jump for many aged care workers from July 1. Economists say the one-offs shouldn't be extrapolated. EY chief economist Cherelle Murphy explains in a note on why the real test on wages will come next quarter. "This strong result is not out of line with the Reserve Bank’s expectations that the WPI will peak at 4 per cent at the end of this year. But the real test will come next quarter and in 2024," she said. "The Reserve Bank expects wages growth will slow in line with the slight easing of labour demand indicators as productivity growth recovers. The bank’s business liaison program has also reported a larger share of firms expecting wages growth in a years’ time will be below its current rate. "Today's result alone will not convince the Reserve Bank that another rate hike is needed at its December Board meeting – given the increase in wages this quarter was within their expectations. The risks are tilted towards another rate hike in the new year – given the labour market remains tight and medium-term inflation expectations have ticked up a little. The impact on inflation from these risks will be worse if productivity outcomes remain poor."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Real test on wages will come next quarter: EY

children.content: The September quarter wage growth was the strongest on record, annual pay rise
was the biggest since March 2009.
Base wages rose 1.3 per cent over the three months to September and 4 per cent over the past year.
Wages were pushed higher by a 5.75 per cent boost for workers on awards and a 15 per cent pay jump for many aged care workers from July 1.
Economists say the one-offs shouldn't be extrapolated.
EY chief economist Cherelle Murphy explains in a note on why the real test on wages will come next quarter.

"This strong result is not out of line with the Reserve Bank’s expectations that the WPI will peak at 4 per cent at the end of this year. But the real test will come next quarter and in 2024," she said.

"The Reserve Bank expects wages growth will slow in line with the slight easing of labour demand indicators as productivity growth recovers. The bank’s business liaison program has also reported a larger share of firms expecting wages growth in a years’ time will be below its current rate.

"Today's result alone will not convince the Reserve Bank that another rate hike is needed at its December Board meeting – given the increase in wages this quarter was within their expectations. The risks are tilted towards another rate hike in the new year – given the labour market remains tight and medium-term inflation expectations have ticked up a little. The impact on inflation from these risks will be worse if productivity outcomes remain poor."

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Top and bottom movers in afternoon trade

children.content: (Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The push to legalise cannabis for recreational use in Australia just got another boost from a former AFP chief commissioner. At a speech in Melbourne, Mick Palmer AO said cannabis law reform would lead to less discrimination and spending on enforcement. The retired police officer spent many years in the field, including in the Northern Territory, where he says he saw many examples of Indigenous Australians being discriminated against, under laws that once banned them from drinking alcohol. He reminded people listening in the crowd that homosexual acts and suicide had also once been illegal. "Police, too often, in my view, are seen as a ‘cure all’," he said. "The cadre of people most in need of support, treatment and protection are those most likely to be punished. "There has to be a better, more effective, less damaging way to deal with people who use cannabis, than simply arresting them." Palmer was sworn is as the top police officer in the country in 1994 and, during his reign as AFP commissioner, conducted the Palmer Inquiry into the unlawful detention of Australian citizen, Cornelia Rau. He made this speech for one of Australia's most renowned authorities on drug reform. The Penington Institute recently changed its position on cannabis legalisation, and now argues that it should be made lawful in "a strictly regulated market that prioritises safety and health outcomes". "On the basis of long and painful legislative history lessons, it is a position that is hard to argue against," Mr Palmer said. "To do so I suggest, would go a long way towards leaving a truly courageous legacy." The former AFP commissioner's comments come just days after ABC News published a story into the growing push to nationally legalise Australia's most commonly consumed illicit substance. The Greens say legalisation could lead to an economic boom, and medicinal marijuana companies agree, although they are in dispute with the Greens about the best way to achieve this.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former AFP commissioner supports cannabis law reform

featuredLink.title: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

children.content: The push to legalise cannabis for recreational use in Australia just got another boost from a former AFP chief commissioner.
At a speech in Melbourne, Mick Palmer AO said cannabis law reform would lead to less discrimination and spending on enforcement.

The retired police officer spent many years in the field, including in the Northern Territory, where he says he saw many examples of Indigenous Australians being discriminated against, under laws that once banned them from drinking alcohol.
He reminded people listening in the crowd that homosexual acts and suicide had also once been illegal.
"Police, too often, in my view, are seen as a ‘cure all’," he said.
"The cadre of people most in need of support, treatment and protection are those most likely to be punished.
"There has to be a better, more effective, less damaging way to deal with people who use cannabis, than simply arresting them."

Palmer was sworn is as the top police officer in the country in 1994 and, during his reign as AFP commissioner, conducted the Palmer Inquiry into the unlawful detention of Australian citizen, Cornelia Rau.
He made this speech for one of Australia's most renowned authorities on drug reform.

The Penington Institute recently changed its position on cannabis legalisation, and now argues that it should be made lawful in "a strictly regulated market that prioritises safety and health outcomes".
"On the basis of long and painful legislative history lessons, it is a position that is hard to argue against," Mr Palmer said.
"To do so I suggest, would go a long way towards leaving a truly courageous legacy."
The former AFP commissioner's comments come just days after ABC News published a story into the growing push to nationally legalise Australia's most commonly consumed illicit substance.
The Greens say legalisation could lead to an economic boom, and medicinal marijuana companies agree, although they are in dispute with the Greens about the best way to achieve this.
